image.altText: Joe Biden points as he speaks into a microphone while standing in front of a US flag.

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden announces he is standing down from his re-election campaign and putting his support behind Vice-President Kamala Harris as the Democratic presidential nominee in the 2024 election.

title.children: Joe Biden gives into pressure and pulls out of 2024 election

image.altText: Kamala Harris looks on as Joe Biden stands in front

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden is ending his re-election bid and pulling out of this year's presidential race, throwing his support behind his Vice-President Kamala Harris. Follow live.

title.children: Joe Biden quits presidential race to throw support behind Kamala Harris

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Kamala Harris has issued a statement
Barack Obama says the decision is 'a testament to Joe Bidenâ€™s love of country'
Trump says Biden 'is not fit to serve'

image.altText: Lindsay Thomas stands in bush.

props.synopsis: Port Augusta is turning into a battleground for Labor and the Coalition's opposing solutions to reducing carbon emissions, with some threatening legal action if the Coalition wins government.

title.children: Port Augusta First Nations group considers legal battle over proposed nuclear power plant

image.altText: emergency services at Carlton rail station after a father and his daughter were killed by an oncoming train

props.synopsis: The bodies of a father and one of his twin two-year-old daughters are removed from Carlton rail station after the girls' pram rolled on the tracks.

title.children: Investigators assess vision from moments before 'hero' father tried to save twin daughters from oncoming train

image.altText: Close up of sign saying Unley Oval

props.synopsis: "Misinformation" and community "division" â€” it sounds like the latest report about the upcoming American presidential election. In fact it's a sleepy suburb in Adelaide's inner-south where a proposal to build a fence has ignited online fury.

title.children: 'Storm in teacup' erupts over council proposal to return fencing to home of Double Blues

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair.

props.synopsis: Like her mother, Tarnika became addicted to drugs and went to prison. The number of First Nations women being incarcerated is on the rise.

title.children: Homelessness, addiction and prison: The rising rates of women incarcerated

image.altText: Two men sitting on a plane wearing face masks.

props.synopsis: Australian passengers have been left stranded overseas after a major IT outage on Friday evening caused thousands of flights to be delayed, and in some cases cancelled.

title.children: Australians left stranded overseas as airlines scramble to recover from major IT outage

image.altText: A man wearing a dark hoodie pictured from behind, in front of a business called "Harlots".

props.synopsis: William says he and other NDIS participants have the same wants and aspirations as anybody else â€” and a sex work ban would deny a whole section of the community from a "deeply ingrained human need" based just on their circumstances.

title.children: NDIS participants using sex workers fear ban will deny some people with disability a 'normal life'

image.altText: A man installs supports for solar panels at a construction site.

props.synopsis: At least one solar project has been put on hold indefinitely, as some energy investors grow nervous over whether renewables will still be supported under the Coalition's nuclear proposal.Â

title.children: Solar industry sees first projects put on ice as nuclear proposal sows doubt among investors

image.altText: a boy and a girl smile at camera in front of a swimming pool wearing South Australia jumpers

props.synopsis: Young swimmers in Kyle Chalmers' home town are drawing plenty of inspiration from the Olympic medallist as they dive in for training on cold winter mornings.Â

title.children: Port Lincoln kids gun for hometown hero Kyle Chalmers' records as Games excitement builds

image.altText: A crowd of people hold up signs saying NEVER SURRENDER and TRUMP VANCE

props.synopsis: In Michigan, Donald Trump held court in front of a mostly adoring crowd of 15,000 spectators, making clear how quickly last week's event has become an almost mystical element in the Trump story.

title.children: If Trump's Grand Rapids rally showed us anything, it's that the calls for unity will never be as loud as those for 'fight, fight, fight'

image.altText: Police officers patrol in front of the Eiffel Tower.

props.synopsis: Staring down 10 million visitors and 10,000 athletes expected to pour in for the Paris Olympics, France's terror alert is at its highest level with the country facing "a challenging time" to host the Games.

title.children: How worried should you be about terrorism threats at the Paris Olympics?

image.altText: A missile is fired from a ship over water, with an island in the background.

props.synopsis: The test was conducted at the Rim of the Pacific (RIMPAC) exercise, hosted by the United States off the coast of Hawaii.

title.children: 'Major milestone' as Australian Navy tests out its new Naval Strike Missile during US-hosted military exercises

image.altText: Worker welding

props.synopsis: A study by Curtin University has found 90 per cent of welders are being exposed to carcinogenic welding fumes, some at high levels. A public health expert and union official say the issue needs to be taken as seriously as silica and asbestos exposure.

title.children: When Mark inhaled too many fumes as a welding apprentice, he was told to drink 'a cup of milk'

image.altText: A woman looks at the myTax website on a computer screen, resting her head on her hand

props.synopsis: The government announced it was changing the HECS indexation rates a few months ago, but the legislation hasn't passed parliament yet.Â

title.children: Expecting a HECS refund? Here's why you'll have to wait for it

image.altText: The CrowdStrike branding is seen on teh front of an office building

props.synopsis: Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil says it may take one to two weeks to get all affected sectors "completely back online" following Friday's major IT outage, caused by a software update by global cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike.

title.children: 'Teething issues' following CrowdStrike outage could take 'one or two weeks' to resolve, Clare O'Neil says

image.altText: A sign in a window which says Networ Outage hope to open soon

props.synopsis: CrowdStrike became a household name on Friday for all the wrong reasons. Here's what we know about them.

title.children: How a group of tech 'rebels' triggered the world's biggest IT meltdown

image.altText: Charlie Cameron hits is chest as he celebrates an AFL goal for the Lions.

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lions coach Chris Fagan praises the fighting spirit of his team after they stretch their winning streak to seven matches with a thrilling two-point win over the Sydney Swans.

title.children: 'Never give up': How the Lions overcame ladder-leading Swans to clinch top-four spot

image.altText: A composite image of Nathan Cleary and Tom Trbovejic in seperate matches

props.synopsis: Some of the biggest names in the NRL have played starring roles for crucial wins on Sunday.

title.children: Big stars rise to the occasion as Cleary nails comeback and Turbo torches the Titans

image.altText: Cigarettes in plain packaging with graphic health warnings, with smoke superimposed over the top

props.synopsis: Australia's tobacco excise is "well past its point of effectiveness", according to one expert, who says it's pushing smokers onto the black market, hurting retailers and taxpayers.

title.children: If smoking rates have 'flatlined' why are tobacconists 'popping up everywhere'? The maths, it seems, is up in smoke

image.altText: The front of a hotel in Thailand.

props.synopsis: Investors meet at a luxury hotel in Bangkok to try to get their money back, but none leave alive and now Thai police and the FBI are investigating an apparent murder-suicide by cyanide poisoning.

title.children: A group of investors walked into a Thai hotel room to recover their money, but none came out alive

image.altText: A wall of red: fire and smoke above silhouettes of buildings.

props.synopsis: Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthi movement says it fired several missiles at the Israeli port city of Eilat.Â

title.children: Israel says it intercepted missile fired by Houthis at southern city of Eilat

image.altText: Oscar Piastri sprayed with champange after winning the Hungarian Grand Prix

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri has become the fifth Australian to win a Formula 1 grand prix, taking the chequered flag for McLaren in Hungary.

title.children: Oscar Piastri takes his maiden grand prix win after dramatic final laps

image.altText: parents assisting daughter on pony ride

props.synopsis: The community comes together to grant Audrey Wallace her dream party after being housebound and spending so many milestones in hospital.Â

title.children: A month ago, this dying six-year-old's family was struggling. Today she rode a rainbow unicorn

image.altText: SES Penrith

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology says the worst of the weather compared to the past two days is over, as winds continue to ease in south-eastern parts of the country throughout the afternoon and evening.

title.children: Severe weather easing across south-east Australia as SES teams work to restore power lines, remove fallen trees

image.altText: A woman holds pamphlets in her hand as she stands on the footpath. Behind her is a sign that says 'Babies lives matter'.

props.synopsis: At stake in the upcoming US election is something Americans once took for granted â€” and Donald Trump helped take away.

title.children: Lynn has been protesting outside abortion clinics for 51 years. She's 'definitely' voting for Trump

image.altText: A newly married couple hold hands at their wedding.

props.synopsis: In a more diverse world, with a dizzying array of dating apps to introduce us to a wider pool of potential partners than our grandparents care to imagine, how much is our choice of romantic partner changing? Tell us your love stories.

title.children: I've noticed something odd about most couples. Psychologists and geneticists have noticed it too

image.altText: A man in a suit standing in front of a purple screen

props.synopsis: Green hydrogen might be more efficient than petrol but it doesn't rate against a battery-driven vehicle, and funding it is proving to be difficult with iron ore prices falling.

title.children: Why Andrew Forrest stepped back on green hydrogen

image.altText: An illustration of a briefcase with cash coming out. The whole image is glitching.

props.synopsis: From cryptocurrency to video games, criminals are turning to some surprising digital technologies to help launder money.

title.children: How do modern criminals launder money? Some are doing it by playing video games

image.altText: A medicine bottle with a tag warning the medicine may cause drowsiness

props.synopsis: Experts are worried about a proliferation of "single-issue" cannabis clinics opening in Australia, some of them willing to prescribe via telehealth consultations with few checks.

title.children: Doctors warn of significant increase in people hospitalised with psychosis after being prescribed medicinal cannabis

image.altText: Prince George of Wales and Prince William hug each other in the box of a soccer stadium

props.synopsis: During the UEFA Euro final the whole world saw the warmth of Prince William and Prince George's relationship. In a family fractured with discord and burdened with ill-health, this was a tonic.

title.children: In a fractured royal family, Prince William and George's show of joy at the Euro final was a tonic

image.altText: A paddock of dairy cows on rolling hills

props.synopsis: Seafood waste is being made into fertiliser and a cheese boiler plant runs on wood waste in the small New South Wales town. Could this be the future of sustainability?

title.children: The boss of Bega cheese heard the Netherlands wanted to become a circular economy. Now he wants it for his town

image.altText: A welcome to Canberra, Australia's capital sign with graffiti below reading "of weird rules".

props.synopsis: Newcomers to Canberra are often struck by the absence of front fences, which is the result of just one of the obscure rules in place in the nation's capital.

title.children: It's been 100 years since front fences were banned in Canberra â€” but that's not the only quirky ACT law

image.altText: A vapour trail in a sunset sky over the ocean, and silhouettes of palm trees.

props.synopsis: Five years after Starlink satellites started orbiting the Earth, Pacific Island countries are still weighing up its benefits despite calls to approve its services.

title.children: Elon Musk's Starlink satellites promise to connect the Pacific to the internet. So why are some countries trying to ban it?

image.altText: Thermal image of a concrete surface with a wire fence behind it.

props.synopsis: Some 34 years after operations closed at the North Cliff mining site in Dharawal National Park, vision given to the ABC shows methane gas leaking out into the atmosphere.

title.children: A gas '80 times more harmful than CO2' is seeping out of a Sydney mine not used in decades
